ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Individual meetings with Ms. Liu.
weekly tutorials sessions over zoom
Two additional one-on-one speaking sessions per week.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Dramatically improving Chinese knowledge.
Further developed my knowledge of Chinese Language
I definitely felt that my language vocabulary was expanded. Additionally, my listening and speaking skills developed significantly.
My Chinese skills
I learned some spoken and written Chinese

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No real weaknesses -- maybe just going at a *slightly* slower pace to allow for longer-term memory retention of grammar and vocabulary.

This course's material was great. I learned many new words and grammar structures. 
I felt like it was hard to have enough student participation over zoom.
I wish that homework was due at the start of class rather than at 9am. It was a weird disadvantage for our later class to have to do homework during a shorter window of time.
Its strength was giving us a rigorous foundation of Chinese. However, I did not find it particularly engaging.
The course material was outdated and dull, and there wasn't enough feedback on speaking or writing. Positives were a great sense of community.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think all were good.
Trying to run this class over zoom was an overall challenge. It relies so heavily on class participation that making it virtual strongly hinders the overall experience.
I felt that the class did a very suitable job adapting to the pandemic. There is nothing in particular I would change.
The canvas was terribly organized, but the daily work calender was useful. There was no easy way to see what work still remained to be done.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely.
Yes, this course was definitely a helpful step in improving my Chinese language skils.
This is a very solid intermediate Chinese class. However, Im not sure when I would recommend this to a student unless this was already obviously their next step in their Chinese language journey.

I would only recommend it to a student who was really interested in taking Chinese. If the student were only taking it for a distributional requirement, then I would not recommend it unless they had already tested into it.
No, I lost my desire to learn Chinese in this course, and only got it back after watching some Chinese media after the semester.
